Award.AwardTitle: SAVI: Collaborative Research: Overturning in the Subpolar North Atlantic - Labrador Basin and Floats
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is one of two components of a US-led international program, Overturning in the Sub-polar North Atlantic (OSNAP), designed to provide a continuous record of the full-water column, trans-basin fluxes of heat, mass and freshwater in the subpolar North Atlantic. The OSNAP observing system consists of two legs: one extending from southern Labrador to the southwestern tip of Greenland across the mouth of the Labrador Sea (OSNAP West), and the second from the southeastern tip of Greenland to Scotland (OSNAP East). The observing system also includes subsurface floats (OSNAP Floats) in order to trace the pathways of overflow waters in the basin and to assess the connectivity of currents crossing the OSNAP line. The location of the OSNAP East and West legs purposefully melds with a number of long-term observational efforts in the North Atlantic: the Canadian repeat hydrography program in the Labrador Sea; the German Labrador Sea western boundary array at 53°N; the global Ocean Observatories Initiative node to be placed in the southwestern Irminger Sea; the repeat hydrographic sections across the Irminger and Iceland basins; and the Ellett line in the Rockall region. Substantial international collaboration has been garnered for OSNAP, including measurement contributions from the UK, Germany, the Netherlands and Canada. Importantly, this proposed observing system, in conjunction with the RAPID/MOCHA array at 26°N and the European Union NACLIM program at Nordic Seas overflows, will provide the first comprehensive three-dimensional measure of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and provide a means to evaluate inter-gyre connectivity in the North Atlantic.

This collaborative project will implement the OSNAP West section and the OSNAP Float program. The primary observational components are: (i) a mooring array across the eastern margin of the Labrador Sea, where the subpolar boundary current enters the basin. This array will complement an analogous array across the western margin at the exit point of the Labrador Sea, maintained by institutions in Germany and Canada; (ii) a sequential release of acoustically tracked floats in the lower limb of the AMOC at the OSNAP East and OSNAP West boundary arrays. These floats will be seeded in the two densest components of North Atlantic Deep Water (NADW) over the four-year period of the measurement program (2014-2018).

Intellectual Merit: For decades oceanographers have understood the AMOC to be highly susceptible to changes in the production of NADW. However, a number of recent observational and modeling studies have called into question this supposition, as more has been learned about the role of wind forcing in AMOC variability. Thus, the overall goal of this project is to establish an observing system that will determine the role that intermediate and deep water mass formation and basin-scale wind forcing play in the overturning and associated poleward heat transport, assessments that currently have only been theorized and modeled, but not observed.

Broader Impact: In January of 2007, the US Joint Subcommittee on Ocean Science and Technology identified the study of the AMOC as one of four near-term priorities in the US Ocean Research Priorities Plan. This proposed work directly addresses that priority via a design of an AMOC observing system in the sub-polar North Atlantic. While a primary motivation for studying AMOC variability comes from its potential impact on the climate system, additional motivation for the measure of the heat, mass and freshwater fluxes in the sub-polar North Atlantic arises from their potential impact on marine biogeochemistry and the cryosphere. There is growing evidence that the ocean has played (and is playing) a role in the reduction of Arctic sea ice and in mass loss from the Greenland Ice Sheet - both of which have been attributed to changes in the poleward heat transport by the ocean. Also, the ocean plays an essential role in the carbon cycle by moderating increasing atmospheric concentrations of CO2 through the sequestration of anthropogenic carbon in the deep ocean. Variability in the AMOC is expected to impact this sequestration. Broader impacts also include the training of five graduate students in seagoing operations and in the processing and analysis of observational data. The graduate students will have an opportunity to collaborate with their international counterparts through virtual meetings and in-person visits and will be mentored by multiple advisors.

This research award includes support for a Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) that is co-funded by NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OSNAP West mooring program

A fundamental component of the circulation in the North Atlantic ocean
is an overturning cell whereby warm water flows northward in the
surface layer, and cold water flows southward at depth. When the warm
water reaches high latitudes, it cools and becomes more dense due to
heat loss to the atmosphere. The water subsequently sinks and returns
equatorward within a deep system of currents. This process results in
a net northward transport of heat by the ocean, which is critical for
maintaining Earth's climate. The overturning cell is referred to as
the "Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation", or AMOC. Our
project, called "Overturning in the Subpolar North Atlantic Program"
(OSNAP), was designed to directly measure the AMOC for the first time
at high latitudes. We maintained a
tightly-spaced array of moorings extending across the continental
shelf and slope of West Greenland (Figure 1a). When combined with
similar mooring arrays and complimentary measurements that together
sampled from the coast of Labrador to the coast of Scotland, we
quantified the strength and variability of the AMOC from
2014-2018. This revealed that the overturning varies markedly on a
month-to-month basis, and that most of it occurs to the east of
Greenland.

Our West Greenland mooring array data were also used to quantify the characteristics and strength of the local circulation in the southeast Labrador
Sea.  Three different components were identified: a coastal current
on the inner shelf, a current in the vicinity of the shelfbreak, and a
deep current at the base of the continental slope (Figure 1b). These
components transported different types of water which varied in their
properties and flow strength over the course of the year. This was due
to a combination of forcing factors, including remote winds and
ocean-atmosphere heat exchange.

Numerous other studies were undertaken during the project to
investigate the sources of dense water feeding the deep component of
the boundary current. Dense water flows southward through two gaps in the ridge: one in Denmark Strait between Greenland and Iceland, and one south of the Faroe Islands in the Faroe Bank Channel. After progressing through the
gaps the dense water sinks, forming the lower limb of the AMOC. Using
historical data we quantified the dense water pathways approaching the ridge, including a newly-discoverd current feeding the Faroe Bank Channel. We traced this water upstream to where it is
densified at the sea surface during the winter months. Notably, the
densest water flowing through both the eastern and western gaps in the
ridge emanates from the same location within Greenland Sea. This
discovery will help us understand how this part of the AMOC might
respond to a changing climate.

OSNAP floats

In the past, the pathways of the deep cold currents that make up the lower limb of the AMOC were pieced together from sparse observations that were widely separated in space and/or time, providing only a rudimentary description of the current patterns. As part of OSNAP, the first direct measurements of the pathways of these deep currents were collected using freely drifting buoys that drifted with the deep currents for up to two years.  The buoys were tracked underwater using an array of sound beacons that were set in place before the first buoys were deployed. A total of 138 buoys were launched during OSNAP, at depths between 1800 and 2800 meters. Figure 2 shows the trajectories of all the buoys.

The buoy trajectories showed that the pathways of the deep AMOC currents are much more complex than previously known. In the past, oceanographers thought that the deep AMOC currents mainly followed a circuitous counter-clockwise path around the perimeter of the subpolar North Atlantic. The buoy trajectories revealed that this is true in some regions, but not others. In several locations, deep current branches break away from the perimeter path. For example, the deep current following the eastern flank of the Reykjanes Ridge in the Iceland Basin was previously thought to all turn westward into the Irminger Basin after passing through a deep cut in the ridge called the Charlie-Gibbs Fracture Zone. The buoy trajectories and trajectories simulated with a numerical model both showed that some water transported by the deep AMOC passes the entrance of the fracture zone and continues southward along the flank of the ridge. Another surprising result was that deep currents flowing westward through the fracture zone did not turn northward to follow the perimeter of the Irminger Basin, but instead spread westward and southward. Finally, the buoys were trapped in many deep eddies (evident from their looping motion), revealing the importance of these small swirling features in the spreading of the deep waters of the subpolar North Atlantic.

These and many other results from our project are published in peer-reviewed scientific journals.
